Data.event_text: 2 January  COVID-19 in the UK A record high daily positive test figure is reported at 57,725, as the new strain of the virus continues to spread.

links.text: -"Hospitals across UK 'must prepare for Covid surge', senior doctor warns". BBC News. 2 January 2021. Archived from the original on 2 January 2021. Retrieved 2 January 2021.-
-"Hospitals across UK 'must prepare for Covid surge', senior doctor warns". BBC News. 2 January 2021. Archived from the original on 2 January 2021. Retrieved 2 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: In a televised address, Boris Johnson announces a new, third COVID-19 lockdown for England, with people ordered to stay at home, and all schools and colleges to switch to remote learning from 5 January. This is expected to last until at least mid-February.

links.text: -"Covid: New lockdown for England amid 'hardest weeks'". BBC News. 4 January 2021. Retrieved 4 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: A new record high daily positive test figure is reported at 58,784.

links.text: -"COVID-19: UK records 58,784 new coronavirus cases â€“ highest daily total since pandemic started". Sky News. 4 January 2021. Retrieved 5 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: The UK's second vaccine against COVID-19, developed by OxfordAstraZeneca, begins to be rolled out.

links.text: -"Covid: Brian Pinker, 82, first to get Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine". BBC News. 4 January 2021. Retrieved 4 January 2021.-
-Weaver, Matthew (4 January 2021). "Oxford man, 82, first in world to get Oxford/AstraZeneca Covid vaccine". The Guardian. Retrieved 4 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: Most of England's primary schools reopen after the Christmas break, amid concerns over whether pupils should be returning during the current level of COVID infections. Most schools close again the following day.

links.text: -Coughlan, Sean (4 January 2021). "Uncertainty as primary pupils return in England". BBC News. Retrieved 4 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: The Joint Biosecurity Centre recommends that the COVID-19 alert level is moved from 4 to 5, indicating a "material risk of healthcare services being overwhelmed".

links.text: -"UK Covid alert level at highest rating as NHS at risk of being 'overwhelmed'". ITV News. 4 January 2021. Retrieved 5 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: Nicola Sturgeon announces tougher restrictions for mainland Scotland to contain the new strain of the virus, implementing a stay-at-home order from midnight and delaying the return to school for pupils until February.

links.text: -"Covid in Scotland: Scots ordered to stay at home in new lockdown". BBC News. 4 January 2021. Retrieved 4 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: The extradition of WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange from the UK to the US is blocked by a court in London, due to concerns over his mental health.

links.text: -"Julian Assange: Wikileaks founder extradition to US blocked by UK judge". BBC News. 4 January 2021. Retrieved 4 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: 5 January  COVID-19 in the UK The number of new daily confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the UK surpasses 60,000 for the first time since the pandemic began, at 60,916.

links.text: -"UK records more than 60,000 new coronavirus cases". BBC News. 5 January 2021. Retrieved 5 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: Education Secretary Gavin Williamson announces that GCSE and A-Level exams in England this summer will be replaced by teacher assessments, telling MPs he would "trust in teachers rather than algorithms".

links.text: -Coughlan, Sean (6 January 2021). "Teachers' grades will replace exams in England". BBC News. Retrieved 6 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: Another record daily case figure is reported, with 62,322 new infections. The daily number of deaths from the virus exceeds 1,000 for the first time since April 2020.

links.text: -"UK reports highest daily COVID-19 deaths since April". Reuters. 6 January 2021. Archived from the original on 8 January 2021. Retrieved 6 January 2021.-
-"UK reports highest daily COVID-19 deaths since April". Reuters. 6 January 2021. Archived from the original on 8 January 2021. Retrieved 6 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: 7 January  COVID-19 in the UK Two anti-inflammatory medications, tocilizumab and sarilumab, are found to cut deaths by a quarter in patients who are sickest with COVID-19.

links.text: -"Two more life-saving Covid drugs discovered". BBC News. 7 January 2021. Retrieved 7 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: A third vaccine is approved for public use, made by US company Moderna and offering 94% protection from the virus.

links.text: -"Moderna becomes third Covid vaccine approved in the UK". BBC News. 8 January 2021. Retrieved 8 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: A major incident is declared in London by mayor Sadiq Khan, stating that the spread of the virus is "out of control" in the capital.

links.text: -"Covid-19: 'Major incident' declared by London mayor Sadiq Khan". BBC News. 8 January 2021. Retrieved 8 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: The highest number of daily deaths since the pandemic began is recorded at 1,325. A new record high daily positive test figure is reported at 68,053.

links.text: -"Covid-19: UK sees highest daily toll of 1,325 deaths". BBC News. 8 January 2021. Retrieved 8 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: 9 January  COVID-19 in the UK Buckingham Palace say that the Queen and Prince Philip have both received the first doses of their COVID-19 vaccinations at Windsor Castle.

links.text: -"Covid-19: Queen and Prince Philip receive vaccinations". BBC News. 9 January 2021. Retrieved 9 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: Professor Peter Horby, chair of the government's New and Emerging Respiratory Virus Threats Advisory Group says on The Andrew Marr Show "we are now in the eye of the storm" and "it was bad in March, it's much worse now."

links.text: -"Covid-19: 'Eye of the storm' lockdown warning as cases rise". BBC News. 10 January 2021. Retrieved 10 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: Health Secretary Matt Hancock tells the BBC that everybody in the top four most vulnerable groups will be offered a vaccine by 15 February, while every adult in the UK will be offered one by the autumn.

links.text: -"'Every adult to be offered vaccine by autumn'". BBC News. 10 January 2021. Retrieved 10 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: 11 January  Khairi Saadallah is sentenced to life imprisonment for the murder of three men and the attempted murder of three others during a stabbing in Forbury Gardens in Reading in June 2020.

links.text: -"Reading stabbings: Khairi Saadallah jailed for park murders". BBC News. 11 January 2021. Retrieved 11 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: 13 January  COVID-19 in the UK The highest daily death toll since the pandemic began is recorded, at 1,564.

links.text: -"Covid: UK reports record 1,564 daily deaths". BBC News. 13 January 2021. Retrieved 13 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: 14 January  COVID-19 in the UK The government bans travel from South America and Portugal over concerns of a new Brazilian variant of COVID-19.

links.text: -"Covid Brazilian variant sparks South America travel ban". BBC News. 14 January 2021. Retrieved 14 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: 15 January  COVID-19 in the UK Boris Johnson announces that the UK is to close all travel corridors from 18 January to "protect against the risk of as yet unidentified new strains" of COVID-19, forcing all passengers travelling to the UK to produce a negative test result.

links.text: -"Covid: UK to close all travel corridors from Monday". BBC News. 15 January 2021. Retrieved 15 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: 18 January  COVID-19 in the UK Figures compiled by Our World in Data (OWID) show that the seven-day average for this week in the UK is the highest death rate per million population from COVID-19 of any country in the world after an average of 935 daily deaths were recorded, the equivalent of more than 16 people in every million dying each day from the virus.

links.text: -Cuthbertson, Anthony (18 February 2021). "UK now has highest Covid death rate in the world". The Independent. Archived from the original on 18 January 2021. Retrieved 11 February 2021.-
-Cuthbertson, Anthony (18 February 2021). "UK now has highest Covid death rate in the world". The Independent. Archived from the original on 18 January 2021. Retrieved 11 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: Based on testing for antibodies against SARS-CoV-2, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) estimates that 1 in 10 people across the UK had the virus by December 2020  nearly double the November figure.

links.text: -"One in eight in England had Covid antibodies by December". BBC News. 19 January 2021. Retrieved 19 January 2021.-
-"Coronavirus (COVID-19) Infection Survey: antibody data for the UK, January 2021". ONS. 19 January 2021. Retrieved 19 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: The highest daily death toll since the pandemic began is recorded, at 1,610.

links.text: -"Covid: UK records new daily high of 1,610 deaths". BBC News. 19 January 2021. Retrieved 19 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: A record daily high of 343,000 people are given a COVID-19 vaccination.Royal Navy personnel administering COVID-19 vaccinations in Bristol during early 2021

links.text: -Sabbagh, Dan; Stewart, Heather (20 January 2021). "Record 343,000 people in UK receive Covid vaccine in one day". The Guardian. Retrieved 9 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: The highest daily death toll since the pandemic began is recorded, at 1,820.

links.text: -"Covid: UK reports 1,820 deaths as Johnson warns tough weeks to come". BBC News. 20 January 2021. Retrieved 20 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: A record daily high of 363,508 people are given a COVID-19 vaccination, bringing the total number of first doses so far to 4,973,248 and 464,036 second doses.

links.text: -"COVID-19 vaccine: Record daily number of jabs given, as new UK death figures revealed". Sky News. 21 January 2021. Retrieved 9 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: Glastonbury Festival is cancelled for the second year running as a result of the pandemic.

links.text: -"Glastonbury 2021: Festival axed 'with great regret'". BBC News. 21 January 2021. Retrieved 22 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: Arlene Foster announces that the lockdown in Northern Ireland will be extended to at least 5 March, adding that restrictions may have to remain in place until after the Easter holidays in April.

links.text: -"Covid-19: NI lockdown to be extended until 5 March". BBC News. 21 January 2021. Retrieved 22 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: Storm Christoph Five "danger to life" flood warnings are put in place across North West England and Wales after hundreds of homes are evacuated overnight due to widespread flooding caused by heavy rain and snow.

links.text: -"UK weather â€“ Storm Christoph: Five 'danger to life' weather warnings in place in North West and Wales". Sky News. 21 January 2021. Retrieved 21 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: The R number is reported to have fallen to between 0.8 and 1 for the first time since the beginning of December 2020.

links.text: -"Coronavirus: UK R number 'between 0.8 and 1'". BBC News. 21 January 2021. Retrieved 21 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: The latest analysis of UK data suggests that the new viral strain may be up to 30% deadlier.

links.text: -"Coronavirus: UK variant 'may be more deadly'". BBC News. 22 January 2021. Retrieved 23 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: Four men are jailed for the manslaughter of 39 Vietnamese migrants after they were found dead in a lorry container in Essex in October 2019.

links.text: -"Essex lorry deaths: Men jailed for killing 39 migrants in trailer". BBC News. 21 January 2021. Retrieved 21 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: 25 January  Online retailer Boohoo acquires the Debenhams brand and website for Â£55m after the department store went into administration in April 2020, but it does not retain any of its stores, putting up to 12,000 jobs at risk.

links.text: -"Debenhams shops to close permanently after Boohoo deal". BBC News. 25 January 2021. Retrieved 25 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: 26 January  COVID-19 in the UK Boris Johnson says he is "deeply sorry for every life that has been lost" as the number of deaths from COVID-19 in the UK exceeds 100,000.

links.text: -"Covid deaths: UK passes milestone of 100,000". BBC News. 26 January 2021. Retrieved 26 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: Boris Johnson confirms that schools in England will not be able to reopen to all pupils after the February half-term as planned, but could do so from 8 March "at the earliest". He adds that he hopes a "gradual and phased" relaxation of COVID-19 restrictions can begin in early March.

links.text: -"Covid: English schools could return 8 March 'at the earliest'". BBC News. 27 January 2021. Retrieved 28 January 2021.-
-"Boris Johnson promises plan next month for 'phased' easing of lockdown". BBC News. 27 January 2021. Retrieved 28 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: Home Secretary Priti Patel announces that people travelling from "red list" countries considered to be COVID-19 hotspots will be required to quarantine in government hotels, while anyone wishing to travel abroad will need to prove that they are making an essential trip.

links.text: -"Covid: Would-be travellers must prove journey is essential â€“ Patel". BBC News. 27 January 2021. Retrieved 28 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: 28 January  COVID-19 in the UK A third vaccine, Novavax, which will be manufactured in Stockton-on-Tees, is shown to be 89.3% effective against the virus in a two-dose regimen, following large-scale UK trials. 60 million doses are secured by the government.

links.text: -"Covid-19: Novavax vaccine shows 89% efficacy in UK trials". BBC News. 28 January 2021. Retrieved 28 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: 29 January  COVID-19 in the UK A fourth vaccine, Ad26.COV2.S, is shown to be 66% effective against the virus in a one-dose regimen. With 30 million doses ordered, Matt Hancock tells reporters that it could "significantly bolster" the UK's vaccine programme if approved by the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA).

links.text: -"Covid vaccine: Single-dose Johnson & Johnson jab is 66% effective". BBC News. 30 January 2021. Retrieved 31 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: 30 January  COVID-19 in the UK A record daily high of 598,389 people are given a coronavirus vaccination, bringing the total so far to 8,977,329.

links.text: -"Covid-19: Record day for UK vaccinations as total nears 9m". BBC News. 31 January 2021.-

Data.event_text: 31 January  Flu cases are reported to have fallen by more than 95%, reaching the lowest levels seen in 130 years, believed to be due to the COVID-19 lockdown and new health habits.

links.text: -"COVID-19: Lockdowns and new health habits help number of flu sufferers fall to 130-year low". Sky News. 31 January 2021. Retrieved 1 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: The government orders an extra 40 million doses of VLA2001, a vaccine from French biotech company Valneva SE, for availability later in the year and into 2022.

links.text: -"Covid-19: UK orders extra 40m doses of Valneva vaccine". BBC News. 1 February 2021. Archived from the original on 3 February 2021. Retrieved 1 February 2021.-
-"Covid-19: UK orders extra 40m doses of Valneva vaccine". BBC News. 1 February 2021. Archived from the original on 3 February 2021. Retrieved 1 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: Door-to-door testing is launched, in an attempt to contain the spread of a new South African variant of the virus (later known as the Beta variant), after cases are found in Hertfordshire, Surrey, Kent, Walsall, Sefton and three London boroughs.

links.text: -"South African variant of Covid found in eight areas of England". The Guardian. 1 February 2021. Retrieved 1 February 2021.-
-"SA variant: Urgent testing after community cases found". BBC News. 1 February 2021. Retrieved 1 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: Online retailer ASOS acquires the Topshop, Topman and Miss Selfridge brands for Â£330m, but does not retain any of the brands' 70 stores, putting 2,500 jobs at risk.

links.text: -Makortoff, Kalyeena (1 February 2021). "Asos buys Topshop and Miss Selfridge brands for Â£330m". The Guardian. Retrieved 11 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: Public Health England (PHE) says that the UK variant of COVID-19 has mutated again and that they are investigating "worrying" new changes. Tests show cases of the new strain have a mutation called E484K that is present in the South African variant.

links.text: -"UK finds more coronavirus cases with 'concerning' mutations". BBC News. 2 February 2021. Retrieved 2 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: A study by the University of Oxford suggests that a single dose of the OxfordAstraZeneca vaccine could lead to a "substantial" fall in the transmission of COVID-19, and protection is 76% effective during the three months after the first dose is given, rising to 82% after a second dose.

links.text: -"Oxford vaccine could substantially cut spread". BBC News. 2 February 2021. Retrieved 2 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: Captain Sir Tom Moore, who raised over Â£32m for NHS Charities Together, dies at the age of 100 after contracting COVID-19.

links.text: -"Captain Sir Tom Moore dies in hospital with coronavirus". BBC News. 2 February 2021. Retrieved 2 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: 3 February  COVID-19 in the UK The number of people receiving a vaccine dose in the UK exceeds 10 million.

links.text: -"10 million people vaccinated in the UK". BBC News. 3 February 2021. Retrieved 3 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: 4 February  Three people are killed, including an alleged assailant in a road crash, after an attack at the University Hospital Crosshouse and a related stabbing nearby in Kilmarnock, East Ayrshire, Scotland. Police Scotland say the incidents are thought to be connected but not terror-related.

links.text: -"Three killed after attack at hospital in Kilmarnock". The Guardian. 5 February 2021. Retrieved 5 February 2021.-
-"Kilmarnock attacks: Two women and a man die in linked incidents". BBC News. 5 February 2021. Retrieved 5 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK Health Secretary Matt Hancock confirms the government's "ambition" to offer all adults over the age of 50 a first COVID-19 vaccination by the end of May.

links.text: -"Covid: All over-50s in UK to be offered vaccine by May". BBC News. 5 February 2021. Retrieved 7 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: One man is killed and ten people are injured after five stabbing incidents take place in the space of two hours in the London Borough of Croydon. Metropolitan Police describe the stabbings as "needless and abhorrent" and say extra police officers will be deployed across south London.

links.text: -"Croydon stabbings: One killed and 10 injured in spate of attacks". BBC News. 6 February 2021. Retrieved 7 February 2021.-
-"Croydon stabbings: 'Abhorrent' night of violence leaves man dead". BBC News. 6 February 2021. Retrieved 7 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: A not yet peer-reviewed study by the University of Oxford suggests the OxfordAstraZeneca vaccine offers minimal protection against mild disease from the South African variant of the virus but does protect against severe disease. Oxford lead vaccine developer, Professor Sarah Gilbert, says a modified version of the vaccine capable of tackling the South African variant should be ready by the autumn, and that "efforts are underway to develop a new generation of vaccines that will allow protection to be redirected to emerging variants as booster jabs".

links.text: -"Covid: Oxford jab offers less S Africa variant protection". BBC News. 7 February 2021. Retrieved 9 February 2021.-
-"AstraZeneca races to adapt Covid vaccine to variant as South Africa suspends rollout". CNBC News. 8 February 2021. Retrieved 9 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: The number of people receiving a vaccine dose in the UK exceeds 12 million.

links.text: -Gillespie, Tom (7 February 2021). "COVID-19: More than 12 million people receive first dose of vaccine as UK reports another 373 deaths". Sky News. Retrieved 9 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: 810 February  Snow and ice causes travel disruption across much of the country. A temperature of âˆ’17.1Â Â°C is recorded in Altnaharra, Scotland, the lowest reading in the UK since December 2010.

links.text: -"UK weather: Snow disruption continues as temperatures plummet". BBC News. 9 February 2021. Retrieved 9 February 2021.-
-"Rail and road problems as temperatures hit new low of âˆ’17.1C". BBC News. 10 February 2021. Retrieved 10 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK The government announces tough new measures for travellers. UK and Irish residents returning from 33 red list countries will be charged Â£1,750 to quarantine in a government-sanctioned hotel for 10 days, with fines of up to Â£10,000 for those who fail to do so. A prison sentence of up to 10 years is to be introduced for those who lie on their passenger locator forms about visiting a red list country.

links.text: -"Covid-19: Travellers face Â£1,750 cost for England quarantine hotels". BBC News. 9 February 2021. Retrieved 9 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: Cumbria County Council suspends plans for Woodhouse Colliery, the UK's first deep coal mine since 1987, following strong criticism over its environmental damage and carbon emissions.

links.text: -"Whitehaven coal mine plan to be re-examined by council". BBC News. 9 February 2021. Retrieved 9 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: 10 February  David Wilson is sentenced to 25 years imprisonment for 96 sex offences against 51 boys, which he committed between May 2016 and April 2020.

links.text: -"David Wilson: Sex offender who posed as girls online jailed for 25 years". BBC News. 10 February 2021. Retrieved 12 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: A study finds that the arthritis drug tocilizumab can reduce deaths from COVID-19, enough to save the lives of one in 25 patients admitted to hospital, and can reduce the need for a mechanical ventilator.

links.text: -"Arthritis drug tocilizumab cuts deaths from Covid". BBC News. 11 February 2021. Retrieved 12 February 2021.-
-"Covid: Arthritis drug tocilizumab could save one in 25 coronavirus patients, study finds". Sky News. 11 February 2021. Retrieved 12 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: The number of people receiving a vaccine dose in the UK exceeds 14 million.
The Met Office reports an overnight temperature of âˆ’22.9Â Â°C in Braemar, Aberdeenshire, the coldest weather in the UK since 1995.

links.text: -"Temperature of âˆ’22.9C in Braemar 'UK's lowest in 26 years'". BBC News. 11 February 2021. Retrieved 11 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: The UK's R rate falls to between 0.7 and 0.9, its lowest level since July 2020.

links.text: -"Covid: Virus cases are going down across the UK". BBC News. 12 February 2021. Retrieved 12 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: The number of people who have been infected by the virus since the start of the pandemic exceeds four million.
The ONS reports that the UK economy shrank by 9.9% during 2020, its largest annual contraction since the Great Frost of 1709.

links.text: -"UK economy suffered record annual slump in 2020". BBC News. 12 February 2021. Retrieved 12 February 2021.-
-"UK suffers worst annual economic slump since the Great Frost of 1709, a 9.9% decline". CNBC. 12 February 2021. Retrieved 12 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: The Supreme Court rules that oil-polluted Nigerian communities can sue Shell in English courts.

links.text: -"Shell in Nigeria: Polluted communities 'can sue in English courts'". BBC News. 12 February 2021. Retrieved 12 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: 14 February  COVID-19 in the UK The number of people receiving a vaccine dose in the UK exceeds 15 million.

links.text: -"Covid-19: More than 15 million in UK have first vaccine jab â€“ Nadhim Zahawi". BBC News. 14 February 2021. Retrieved 14 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: 15 February  COVID-19 in the UK Boris Johnson hails the vaccine rollout as an "unprecedented national achievement" and urges the public to remain "optimistic but patient" over the relaxation of restrictions, adding that an approach to exiting lockdown should be "cautious but irreversible".

links.text: -"Covid-19: PM urges 'optimistic but patient approach' to pandemic". BBC News. 15 February 2021. Retrieved 25 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: 18 February  COVID-19 in the UK Figures from Imperial College London's React study suggests that COVID-19 infections have dropped by two-thirds across England since lockdown began in January, with an 80% fall in London.

links.text: -"Strong decline in coronavirus across England since January, React study shows". BBC News. 18 February 2021. Retrieved 25 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex confirm they will not return as working members of the Royal Family.

links.text: -"Harry and Meghan not returning as working members of Royal Family". BBC News. 19 February 2021. Retrieved 19 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: The Supreme Court rules that Uber drivers must be treated as workers, rather than self-employed, and should therefore be entitled to minimum wage and holiday pay.

links.text: -"Uber drivers are workers not self-employed, Supreme Court rules". BBC News. 19 February 2021. Retrieved 19 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: The High Court rules that Matt Hancock "acted unlawfully by failing to comply with the Transparency Policy" and "breached his legal obligation to publish Contract Award Notices within 30 days" when awarding contracts during the COVID-19 pandemic. Hancock explained the delay in publishing the contracts as being on average "just after a fortnight late", and reasoned it was "because my team were working seven days a week, often 18 hours a day, to get hold of the equipment that was saving lives".

links.text: -"Covid: Matt Hancock acted 'unlawfully' over pandemic contracts". BBC News. 19 February 2021. Retrieved 19 February 2021.-
-"Coronavirus: 'Right' to delay contract transparency in pandemic, says Hancock". BBC News. 21 February 2021. Retrieved 22 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK Boris Johnson pledges to donate most of the UK's surplus vaccine supply to poorer countries.

links.text: -"Covid vaccines: Boris Johnson pledges surplus to poorer countries at G7". BBC News. 19 February 2021. Retrieved 19 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: 20 February  COVID-19 in the UK As the number of people receiving their first vaccine dose exceeds 17 million, Boris Johnson announces he wants the programme to "go further and faster" by offering every adult in the UK their first jab by 31 July.

links.text: -"Covid vaccine: All UK adults to be offered jab by 31 July â€“ PM". BBC News. 21 February 2021. Retrieved 25 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: 22 February  COVID-19 in the UK Boris Johnson unveils a four-step plan for ending lockdown restrictions in England by 21 June. Subject to four tests on vaccines, hospitalisations and deaths, infection rates and new variants being met  the plan's first step will see the reopening of schools and colleges from 8 March.

links.text: -"Lockdown: Boris Johnson unveils plan to end England restrictions by 21 June". BBC News. 22 February 2021. Retrieved 25 February 2021.-
-"COVID-19 Response â€“ Spring 2021 (Summary)". GOV.UK. Retrieved 25 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: 24 February  COVID-19 in the UK Nicola Sturgeon unveils the Scottish Government's "cautious" approach to ending lockdown restrictions in Scotland, which includes a phased return for primary and secondary school pupils from 15 March.

links.text: -"Covid in Scotland: Nicola Sturgeon unveils 'cautious' route out of lockdown". BBC News. 24 February 2021. Retrieved 25 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: 25 February  COVID-19 in the UK The Joint Biosecurity Centre advises that the COVID-19 alert level is downgraded from 5 to 4, indicating that the threat of the NHS being overwhelmed is receding.

links.text: -"UK Covid alert level drops as NHS threat 'reduced'". BBC News. 25 February 2021. Retrieved 25 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: 26 February  Begum v Home Secretary The Supreme Court unanimously rules that Shamima Begum, who left the UK for Syria to join the Islamic State terrorist group and has been stripped of her British citizenship, can lawfully be prevented on security grounds from returning to the UK to appeal her case.

links.text: -"Shamima Begum cannot return to UK, Supreme Court rules". BBC News. 26 February 2021. Retrieved 26 February 2021.-
-"Begum (Respondent) v Secretary of State for the Home Department (Appellant)". The Supreme Court. 26 February 2021. Retrieved 26 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: Six cases of the Brazilian variant of COVID-19 (later known as the Gamma variant) are detected in the UK  three in England and three in Scotland.

links.text: -"Covid-19: Brazil 'variant of concern' detected in UK". BBC News. 28 February 2021. Retrieved 1 March 2021.-

Data.event_text: The number of people receiving a vaccine dose in the UK exceeds 20 million.

links.text: -"Covid-19: More than 20 million in UK have had first jab". BBC News. 28 February 2021. Retrieved 28 February 2021.-

Data.event_text: Winchcombe meteorite Fragments of a rare carbonaceous chondrite meteorite, the first known in the UK, fall at Winchcombe in the Cotswolds.

links.text: -Davis, Josh (9 March 2021). "Fireball meteorite that blazed across the UK recovered from a driveway". Natural History Museum, London. Retrieved 9 March 2021.-

Data.event_text: 1 March  COVID-19 in the UK Data published by Public Health England (PHE) indicates that a single dose of either the OxfordAstraZeneca vaccine or Pfizerâ€“BioNTech vaccine reduces the need for hospitalisation in older adults by more than 80%.

links.text: -"Covid vaccines cut risk of serious illness by 80%". BBC News. 1 March 2021. Retrieved 1 March 2021.-

Data.event_text: 2 March  COVID-19 in the UK Arlene Foster and Michelle O'Neill unveil a "cautious and hopeful" plan for ending lockdown restrictions in Northern Ireland, but unlike England and Scotland there is no timetable for lifting measures. Instead, a five-step plan covering nine different sectors is revealed, with progression based on key health criteria being met.
Murder of Sarah Everard a London woman is kidnapped, raped and strangled by a police officer.

Chancellor of the Exchequer Rishi Sunak delivers his first budget since the pandemic began in which he commits an extra Â£65bn to "protect the jobs and livelihoods of the British people", including an extension to the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme until the end of September, but warns that future tax increases are needed to stop "irresponsible" mounting debt as it is confirmed government borrowing is expected to reach a peacetime record of Â£335bn in 2021.

links.text: -"Budget 2021: Rishi Sunak to extend furlough scheme until September". BBC News. 3 March 2021. Retrieved 5 March 2021.-
-"Budget 2021: Rishi Sunak vows to protect jobs but tax hikes loom". BBC News. 3 March 2021. Retrieved 5 March 2021.-
-"Budget 2021: Key points at-a-glance". BBC News. 4 March 2021. Retrieved 5 March 2021.-

Data.event_text: Figures from the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) forecast the economy to grow by 4% in 2021 and 7.3% in 2022, bringing it back to its pre-pandemic size by mid-2022.

links.text: -"Budget 2021: Rishi Sunak warns tax rises to follow spending spree". BBC News. 3 March 2021. Retrieved 5 March 2021.-

Data.event_text: 4 March  Amazon launches its first cashierless grocery store in the UK, which uses camera vision and sensors to automate the shopping process.

links.text: -"Amazon Fresh till-less grocery store opens in London". BBC News. 4 March 2021. Retrieved 4 March 2021.-

Data.event_text: 5 March  A proposal to give NHS workers a 1% payrise is described by the government as "what is affordable" given the public finances, while unions and others strongly criticise the amount and call for strike action.

Data.event_text: A review by the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) finds that of the 20 million people who received the OxfordAstraZeneca vaccine in the UK up to 31 March 79 people suffered rare blood clots  19 of whom have died.

Data.event_text: 2021 United Kingdom local elections Elections for local councils and directly elected mayors are held in England and police and crime commissioners in England and Wales, including many which were originally due to take place in  but were postponed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
2021 Senedd election Labour keep hold of the Senedd and match the party's best ever result, with 30 out of 60 seats.
2021 Scottish Parliament election The SNP wins 64 seats out of 129. With the SNP and Scottish Greens both gaining seats, pro-independence parties have an increased majority in the Parliament.
2021 London mayoral election Sadiq Khan wins a second term, but with a reduced vote share.
2021 Hartlepool by-election Jill Mortimer becomes the constituency's first Conservative MP since 1974, marking a significant defeat for Labour.

Data.event_text: 2021 Chesham and Amersham by-election Liberal Democrat candidate Sarah Green wins the constituency of Chesham and Amersham with 56.7% of the vote, a swing from the Conservatives of 25.2%. She is the first non-Conservative candidate to win this seat since its formation in 1974.

Data.event_text: 19 June  John Bercow, former Tory MP and Speaker of the House of Commons, defects to Labour, calling his former party "reactionary, populist, nationalistic and sometimes even xenophobic".

links.text: -"John Bercow defects to Labour with withering attack on Johnson". The Guardian. 19 June 2021. Retrieved 20 June 2021.-

Data.event_text: A new Â£50 polymer banknote enters circulation. Featuring the face of computer pioneer and codebreaker Alan Turing, it joins the updated and more secure Â£5, Â£10 and Â£20 notes that were introduced in 2016, 2017 and 2020 respectively.

links.text: -"New Alan Turing Â£50 note design is revealed". BBC News. 25 March 2021. Retrieved 27 March 2021.-

Data.event_text: PC Benjamin Monk is found guilty of the manslaughter of former Aston Villa striker, Dalian Atkinson, who died after being tasered for six times longer than the legally recommended limit, and then kicked twice in the head. Monk becomes the first police officer since the 1980s to be found guilty over a death in custody in England and Wales.

links.text: -"Dalian Atkinson: PC guilty of former footballer's manslaughter". BBC News. 23 June 2021. Retrieved 23 June 2021.-

Data.event_text: Double murderer Gary Allen is sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum term of 37 years following a trial at Sheffield Crown Court in which he was convicted of the murders of two women 21 years apart.

links.text: -"Gary Allen: Killer jailed for murdering two women 21 years apart". BBC News. 23 June 2021. Retrieved 23 June 2021.-

Data.event_text: 25 June  Health Secretary Matt Hancock apologises for breaking social distancing rules after pictures of him kissing an aide, Gina Coladangelo, are published in The Sun newspaper.

links.text: -"Matt Hancock apologises after photos show him kissing aide". The Guardian. 25 June 2021. Retrieved 25 June 2021.-

Data.event_text: Matt Hancock resigns as health secretary, following the previous day's revelations. Sajid Javid is selected as his successor.

links.text: -"Matt Hancock quits as health secretary after breaking social distance guidance". BBC News. 26 June 2021. Retrieved 26 June 2021.-

links.text: -"Classified Ministry of Defence documents found at bus stop". BBC News. 27 June 2021. Retrieved 27 June 2021.-

Data.event_text: COVID-19 in the UK In a televised address, the prime minister, Boris Johnson says he expects that the final lifting of restrictions in England will proceed from 19 July, but this will be confirmed on 12 July after a review of the latest data.

links.text: -"Covid: Most rules set to end in England, says PM". BBC News. 6 July 2021. Retrieved 7 July 2021.-

Data.event_text: 7 July  UEFA Euro 2020 England defeat Denmark 21 after extra time at Wembley in the semi-final. This marks the first time England have reached the final of a major international tournament since 1966. Almost 24 million people are reported to have watched the match on ITV and ITV+1, with a peak of 25.7 million during the last five minutes.

Data.event_text: 8 July  UEFA Euro 2020 UEFA's Control, Ethics and Disciplinary Body (CEDB) charges England following match incidents the previous night. In one, a laser pointer was allegedly shone in the face of Denmark goalkeeper Kasper Schmeichel as he prepared for a penalty. UEFA also notes a "disturbance" during Denmark's national anthem and fireworks being set off.

links.text: -"Euro 2020: England charge by Uefa after 'laser' penalty incident". BBC News. 8 July 2021. Retrieved 8 July 2021.-

Data.event_text: 9 July  Southern Water is fined a record Â£90m for illegally dumping an estimated 16 to 21 billion tons of raw sewage between 2010 and 2015.Supporters at the UEFA Euro 2020 final

Data.event_text: Restrictions are further relaxed in Scotland with changes including 15 people from different households being allowed to meet outdoors, 8 adults indoors and 10 at a pub or restaurant. Booking restrictions at catering facilities are also relaxed and soft play centres can reopen.

The COVID-19 vaccine roll out is expanded to many more under 18s in the UK. Based on scientific advice, the minimum age for vaccinating vulnerable adolescents or those who live with adults that are in a high risk group is reduced from 16 to 12. All young people will now also be eligible for their first dose three months before their 18th birthday.

Data.event_text: 7 September  In the Commons, Johnson reveals the government's long-awaited plan for social care reforms, including a 1.25% rise in National Insurance to raise Â£36bn over three years, and a cap of Â£86,000 on lifetime care costs in England.
